ygData.subject: NEAT Applied to Texas Hold'em Poker

From: "lars_v_hansen" <lvh@...>
Subject: NEAT Applied to Texas Hold'em Poker
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=230616336; y=KXY4GI0EoHXnEzvxfXVb_-CSG2z6JG7bOPqLJZ4Vc6nZJrstJaWLlQ
X-Yahoo-Profile: lars_v_hansen

Hi Everyone

My name is Lars and I am a student at Department of Computer Science,
University of Aarhus, Denmark. I am writing my Master Thesis with my
good friend Mathias who is also a student here ;-). As you probably
already noticed this thesis is about poker (Texas Hold'em) and GAs.

The project is (like many others) inspired by D. Fogels Blondie24 and
we would like to see how well we can learn the ANN players to play
poker without presenting them with explicit expert knowledge about eg.
how many better straights exsists than mine (J. Noble does this).

We have the poker framework and the standard GA with elitism. 


We would like for those of you that are interested in our project to
see the following implementation details.

The framework:
It is coded in Java and has a couple og interfaces such that we can
switch player types between our different ANN players, players based
primarily on pot-odds and of course our own "human-player-gui".

We just recently discovered NEAT (sadly :-() and yesterday we finished
a new player based on jNEAT. The player ANN takes the following
inputs:

1 pot / bet
1 position
9 player actions this round
9 player passive / aggressive index
9 player tight / loose index
2 suit count (4 or 5 siuted cards)
2 connector count (4 or 5 connected cards)
4 card associations (pair, two pairs, three of a kind, four of a kind)
2 hole cards in use ( are we using 1 or 2 hole cards in our hand?)
3 game stage (FLOP/TURN/RIVER)

TOTAL: 45 input neurons

We actually started out with an ANN that had 52 neurons for the cards
and a constant k it could add to the hole cards (Like the kings in
Blondie24). But we realised that it would be very had if not
impossible for the ANN to "see" the good hands and separate them from
the bad ones. Therefore we decided to show the ANN that certain hands
appeard (or almost appeard in connector / suit count). This also
dramaticaly reduced the number of inputs.

The outputs from the ANN are straight forward:
3 neurons:
FOLD | CALL | BET/RAISE

The output neuron that is activated the most is the action we choose
if it is "legal" at the table otherwise we choose the second most
activated and so on.


The fitness of the players:
We have experimented with several settings but the best we have right
now is this: 

The 50 players play against each other and a pot-odds-player
(PO-player) - five of each at each table. They play 600 hands but not
at one table only - we mix them between the tables five times such
that they get to meet different individuals from the entire
population.
The reason we have the PO-players at each table is for the players to
be forced to learn faster and play tighter from the very beginning.

Since we have discovered NEAT we are more open to leaving the
PO-players and going back to strict competitive co-evolution between
our own individuals. We also consider expanding the population to
about 200. But still the problem is here that the weak players at one
table can make only slightly better players at the same table look
very strong compared to really strong players actually competing and
not winning much at another table. Another option is to make a
tournament or like Darse Billings [Alberta GAMES group] suggests: Let
each player take the same position at the table and see who is the
best over-all player.

A major concern is the fitness: We have talked about it for hours and
days but we always come back to the cash of the player. If we cannot
apply expert knowledge - we cannot think of anything else than the
amount earned after x hands.

We would like comments on the above and if possible we would like some
suggestions or answers to the following questions:

1) Is it possible to achieve results with a 45->N->3 ANN in NEAT?

2) Any general comments regarding the population size for the above
ANN?

3) Any parameters we should put in a particular favourable setting?

We use these settings recommended from a NEAT website:

My name is Lars and I am a student at Department of Computer Science,
University of Aarhus, Denmark. I am writing my Master Thesis with my
good friend Mathias who is also a student here ;-). As you probably

1) Is it possible to achieve results with a 45->N->3 ANN in NEAT?

2) Any general comments regarding the population size for the above ANN?

3) Any parameters we should put in a particular favourable setting?

p_trait_param_mut_prob = 0.5;
p_trait_mutation_power = 1;
p_linktrait_mut_sig = 1.0;
p_nodetrait_mut_sig = 0.5;
p_recur_prob = 0;
p_weight_mut_power = 2.5;
p_disjoint_coeff = 1.0;
p_excess_coeff = 1.0;
p_mutdiff_coeff = 0.4;
p_compat_threshold = 3.0;
p_age_significance = 1.0;
p_survival_thresh = 0.2;
p_mutate_only_prob = 0.25;
p_mutate_random_trait_prob = 0.1;
p_mutate_link_trait_prob = 0.1;
p_mutate_node_trait_prob = 0.1;
p_mutate_link_weights_prob = 0.9;
p_mutate_toggle_enable_prob = 0;
p_mutate_gene_reenable_prob = 0;
p_mutate_add_node_prob = 0.03;
p_mutate_add_link_prob = 0.05;
p_interspecies_mate_rate = 0.001;
p_mate_multipoint_prob = 0.6;
p_mate_multipoint_avg_prob = 0.4;
p_mate_singlepoint_prob = 0;
p_mate_only_prob = 0.2;
p_recur_only_prob = 0;
p_pop_size = 50;
p_dropoff_age = 15;
p_newlink_tries = 20;
p_print_every = 10;
p_babies_stolen = 0;
p_num_runs = 1;
p_num_trait_params = 8;

We thank you for any comments and look forward to participate in this
forum.


Best regards

Lars
